title: Consumer confidence hits four-year low
text:
A chief concern for consumers is what is happening on the global stage. During the week of the Westpac MI survey the US share market fell by 2.6 per cent and the Australian market was down by 3 per cent. That same week the RBA cut the official cash rate, by 25 basis points, for the third time this year.

"Global events have, again, contributed to the weak result in October with the deterioration in US-China trade relations weighing on the global economy," Mr Evans said.

"But these events are unlikely to fully explain the sharp fall in the index. Issues that may also be unnerving consumers include the debate around the lack of response of fiscal policy to the deteriorating outlook."

Domestic economy a concern too

Consumer expectations for the economy recorded big falls. Expectations around what the economy would be like in the next five years plunged 9.1 per cent, while expectations of what it would be like in the next 12 months dropped 6 per cent.

One of the key readings – whether it is time to buy major household items – fell by 4.2 per cent, while the time to buy a dwelling index dropped 5.4 per cent.

The only households to show an increase in consumer confidence during the month were those with incomes of between $40,000 to $60,000, whose index picked up marginally from 90.6 points to 91 points.

There were also some positive signs in the labour market, with consumers’ job loss fears receding slightly. The unemployment expectations index declined 1.3 per cent to 131.8 in October.

Advertisement

A lower reading indicates that more consumers expect unemployment to fall in the year ahead.

Expectations on house prices also continued to lift, rising 5.9 per cent in October, up 54.4 per cent since May.

Shadow treasurer Jim Chalmers said the poor consumer confidence reading meant the government was out of touch on what it needed to do to boost economic growth.

"This shows that Australians are worried about the economy," Dr Chalmers said.

"Scott Morrison and Josh Frydenberg are out of touch. Australians are losing confidence rapidly. We call on the government to do something about this floundering consumer confidence."

Dr Chalmers met with Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe and APRA chairman Wayne Byres on Wednesday to discuss the economy.

"I met with Phil Lowe and Wayne Byers and [have been] dealing with some of these issues on consumer confidence," he said.

"I don't want to go into the details of those private conversations. But my view is that the government should not be leaving the heavy lifting to the Reserve Bank.

Advertisement

"If Scott Morrison and Josh Frydenberg had a plan for the economy, the Reserve Bank wouldn't have had to cut rates to below 1 per cent.

"We [Labor] have played a constructive role in suggesting how the government could lift the economy.

"We have suggested the government could bring forward part of its own tax cuts, or infrastructure spending, business investment, a wages policy and a settled energy policy."

Commonwealth Bank economist Belinda Allen said that while consumers had been subjected to a flow of negative news on the economy, their lack of confidence could create a downward spiral.

"Persistently weak consumer sentiment does raise the risk that we do not see an ongoing lift in consumer spending," Ms Allen said.

"The mortgager has experienced the largest fall in sentiment despite being the largest beneficiary of lower interest rates."
description: Consumer confidence has fallen to its lowest level in more than four years as people start to worry about why the Reserve Bank has cut interest rates three times this year.
